elements.title: Rectifier Technologies Ltd Notes to the financial statements 30 June 2022

data.value: Consolidated entity's operations consist of various controlled entities.

As Managing Director of the Pudu Group, Ying Ming has built up a range of technology and property businesses including Epern Telecom Co. Ltd., Beijing’s largest privately owned ISP. He is also involved in the China Digital Kingdom, an internet datacentre development business in China.
Director – Executive and Chief Executive Officer
Master of Law, Bachelor of Philosophy

Before joining Rectifier Technologies as CEO in 2010, Yanbin was Chief Operations Officer at Tianjin IC Card Public Network Company of Tianjin, China and Vice-President of Transtech Sino America, based in Florida, USA. He was instrumental in restructuring the Rectifier Technologies group in 2012, leading it back to growth and profitability.
Master of Science, Bachelor of Science

As a founding director of Rectifier Technologies Pacific, Valentino was instrumental in its product development programs that led the world in telecom power using switch mode technology. He brings the board a significant amount of technical and business expertise.
Director – Executive and Head of Power Engineering

Nigel was a founding director of Rectifier Technologies Pacific and has been involved in all its product development since. Before Rectifier Technologies, Nigel was involved in induction melting equipment at Inductotherm Melting, in sound reinforcement power amplifiers for professional audio at Clockwork Audio, and then in telecom power supplies at Ausmode/Exicom. He has published 8 papers and holds two current patents.

data.value: The attached financial statements and notes comply with the Corporations Act 2001, the Accounting Standards, the Corporations Regulations 2001 and other mandatory professional reporting requirements.
The attached financial statements and notes comply with International Financial Reporting Standards as issued by the International Accounting Standards Board.
The financial statements give a true and fair view of the consolidated entity's financial position as at 30 June 2022.
The financial statements give a true and fair view of the performance for the financial year ended on that date.
There are reasonable grounds to believe that the Company will be able to pay its debts as they become due.
The directors have been given the declarations required by section 295A of the Corporations Act 2001.

The cost of equity-settled transactions are recognised as an expense with a corresponding increase in equity at the vesting date which is at the grant date.

The cumulative charge to profit or loss is calculated based on the grant date fair value of the award, the best estimate of the number of awards that are likely to vest and the expired portion of the vesting period.

If equity-settled awards are modified, an expense is recognised as if the modification has not been made. An additional expense is recognised for any modification that increases the total fair value of the share-based compensation benefit.
If the non-vesting condition is within control of the entity or employee, the failure to satisfy the condition is treated as a cancellation.
If equity-settled awards are cancelled, it is treated as if it has vested on the cancellation date, with remaining expense recognised immediately.
Ordinary shares are classified as equity.
Dividends are recognised when declared during the financial year.
Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing profit attributable to owners, excluding any costs of servicing equity.
Diluted earnings per share adjusts figures to include potential ordinary shares.
Revenues, expenses and assets are recognised net of associated GST unless not recoverable from tax authority.

data.value: Profit reported in the current reporting period despite COVID interruption and global supply chain shortage.
Purchase orders totalling approximately USD 20 million from a major customer in the first half-year of 2022.
Phase 1 of ERP implementation completed; Phase 2 expected to begin in H1 2023.
Continued development of 'RT22 50KW EV Charger Module', with safety certification by TUV SUD expected by Q4 2022.
'Highbury DC Bi-Directional Charger' project put on hold; resources redirected to other developments.
RT22 expected to significantly contribute to company revenue in 2023.

Reflects concessions provided to the customer such as discounts, rebates and refunds, any potential bonuses receivable from the customer and any other contingent events.
Revenue from the sale of power rectifiers and the related after-sales services is recognised at the point when performance obligations are satisfied by delivering promised products and services.
Recognised for consideration received in respect of unsatisfied performance obligations.
Other revenue is recognised when received or when the right to receive payment is established.
Interest revenue is recognised as interest accrued using the effective interest method.
The tax payable on this period's taxable income based on applicable income tax rates, adjusted by changes in deferred tax assets and liabilities.
Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognised for temporary differences at the expected tax rates for recovery or settlement.

Rectifier Technologies Ltd and its wholly-owned Australian subsidiaries have formed an income tax consolidated group. The head entity and each subsidiary account for their own current and deferred tax amounts.
Assets or liabilities arising under tax funding agreements with the tax consolidated entities are recognised as amounts receivable from or payable to other entities in the tax consolidated group.

Assets and liabilities are presented based on current and non-current classification. Assets are classified as current if they are expected to be realized, sold, or consumed in the normal operating cycle, among other conditions.
Deferred tax assets and liabilities are always classified as non-current.
Includes cash on hand, deposits held at call with financial institutions, and other short-term, highly liquid investments with original maturities of three months or less.
Initially recognised at fair value and measured at amortised cost, less allowance for expected credit losses.
Stated at the lower of cost and net realisable value on a 'weighted average' basis and determined after deducting rebates and discounts.
Liabilities for goods and services provided, measured at amortised cost and unpaid.
Initially recognised at fair value, measured at amortised cost using effective interest method.
Recognised at present value of lease payments, discounted using implicit interest rate or incremental borrowing rate.
Capitalised for qualifying assets, expensed for others.
Liabilities measured at amounts expected to be paid when settled.
Liabilities measured at present value of future payments.
Equity-settled compensation measured at fair value on grant date.

This table shows the distribution of shareholdings across different holding ranges. The majority of shares (94.17%) are held by 681 holders who own more than 100,001 shares each. There are 3,086 total shareholders, with 414 holders having less than a marketable parcel. The total number of units is 1,375,700,602.

This table shows the major shareholders and their holdings in the company. UDU Investment (Australia) Pty Ltd is the largest shareholder with 16.33% ownership, followed by Ung Shing with 10.90%. Both Anbin Wang and Malcolm Alistair Duncan hold approximately 5% each. Together, these four shareholders control about 37.35% of the company's issued ordinary shares.

data.value: The consolidated entity would look to raise capital when an opportunity to invest in a business or company was seen as value-adding relative to the current Company's share price at the time of the investment. The consolidated entity is not actively pursuing additional investments in the short term as it continues to integrate and grow its existing businesses in order to maximise synergies.
The capital risk management policy remains unchanged during the current reporting period.
There have been no events of default on the financing arrangements during the financial year.

data.value: The main entry combines foreign currency reserve and share-based payments reserve, which significantly increased from a negative value of -$163.2M in 2021 to $3.26B in 2022. There's also a secondary line item showing a modest increase from $466,825 in 2021 to $513,264 in 2022.
